title: City slippers â€“ does Euro exit await ? Plus : Bellingham backheel , Brady vs Reynolds

Hello! Manchester City are pushing their luck. Will it stretch?

City on the brink: PSG comeback sets up crunch game for Guardiola
The Champions League knockouts are where Manchester City and Pep Guardiola traditionally get out of bed. Itâ€™s a procession to that point, and then the fun begins.
Their consistency is indicative of how powerful a club they are. Yesterday, consultancy firm Deloitte published its annual Money League, ranking global revenues for the gameâ€™s biggest teams. City were second in 2023-24, behind Real Madrid and just ahead of Paris Saint-Germain. All three have designs on ruling the world.
How, then, did two entities as wealthy as City and PSG find themselves scraping the barrel last night in a frantic, mutual bid to avoid early elimination from the Champions League? And how, after a 4-2 defeat in Paris, are City at grave risk of crashing out next week?
PSG were the side on the hook before kick-off, more at risk of humiliation than City. That was an equally chastening reality for their Qatari owners. They didnâ€™t buy PSG in 2011 for football alone (Qatarâ€™s political interests were at play too) but they were there to win â€” specifically, to win the Champions League. They havenâ€™t gone billions deep for the pleasure of making up the numbers.
By overhauling a 2-0 deficit yesterday, they live to fight another day. City, in contrast, trudge on through a season that is not far off a total write-off. They canâ€™t defend (exhibit A: PSGâ€™s third goal, above). They canâ€™t retain a lead. Their shadow isnâ€™t scaring anybody, aside from themselves.
Going into the tie, PSG feared their exit papers would arrive before the postcards sent by their new signing, Khvicha Kvaratskhelia. Instead, City look like going the journey. Either they win their last league-stage match against Club Brugge on Wednesday or the new Champions League format has its first prime victim. Whoâ€™d have thought?
Advertisement
Real riches, Bellingham backheel brilliance
Realâ€™s position at the top of the Deloitte Money League is rock solid. They raked in Â£884million ($1.09bn) from matchday, broadcast and commercial earnings last season, comfortably clear of City (Â£708m) and PSG (Â£681m). Their matchday revenue of Â£209m is extraordinary.
It hasnâ€™t stopped them from experiencing turbulence of their own since they won the Champions League last June and itâ€™s likely to be the play-offs for them, unless the final round of fixtures does them a favour.
They avoided any of Cityâ€™s torment by annihilating Red Bull Salzburg last night and frankly, when they have tricks like Jude Bellinghamâ€™s gorgeous assist for Rodrygo up their sleeve (above), you never write them off.
The standings
So where does this leave us, with the league stage almost done? Itâ€™s a complicated picture and I wonâ€™t beat around the bush because the permutations are too broad and complex to outline in one TAFC.
Fortunately, our colleagues have been grafting to compile a definitive guide to how the table stands, how the play-offs are shaping up and what it all means for future rounds. The last 16 could genuinely end up like Antarctica â€” no City.
News round-up
- A welcome Bloody Mary for City: forward Omar Marmoush is theirs, at a cost of Â£59m. Meanwhile, Kyle Walker is on his way to join Milan on loan.
- Ruben Amorim says it was a mistake to trash a widescreen TV in Manchester Unitedâ€™s dressing room after their weekend defeat to Brighton. â€œI didnâ€™t think.â€
- His mood wonâ€™t be improved by United failing to sign Patrick Dorgu, unless the club can bridge the gap between how much they and Lecce think the left-back is worth. Theyâ€™re Â£8.5m apart.
- Ronald Araujo is ready to sign a contract extension at Barcelona. It sounded like he would be leaving a few weeks ago. Barca are in talks with Pedri too.
- Charlotte FC have sealed the signing of Wilfried Zaha. Heâ€™s taken a year-long loan from Galatasaray.
- Sweden rejected the introduction of a VAR system and now, Norwegian clubs have voted to scrap it. Scandinavia is the resistance.
American Bhoys: Defensive duo help Celtic to next stage of Champions League
Fun and games at Celtic, where Kyogo scored three disallowed goals in the first half alone yesterday. The Bhoys got there in the end, beating Young Boys of Switzerland 1-0. A place in the Champions League knockout stage is theirs.
But The Athleticâ€™s Michael Walker went north to Parkhead in pursuit of a different narrative. Celtic have two Americans in the centre of their defence, Cameron Carter-Vickers and Auston Trusty. Theyâ€™re United States internationals. Theyâ€™re in their prime years and theyâ€™re pushing Celtic towards a 55th Scottish title, while keeping them in Europe. It canâ€™t be a bad sign that theyâ€™ve got their own song (American Bhoys to the tune of Estelleâ€™s hit).
Advertisement
Could they be Mauricio Pochettinoâ€™s pairing for the 2026 World Cup? Thereâ€™s something to be said for a partnership with a clear understanding at club level. Pochettino didnâ€™t need either of them in the USMNTâ€™s 3-0 friendly win over Costa Rica last night â€” but far bigger examinations lie ahead.
Brady vs Reynolds: Will Birmingham and Wrexham hit cash roadblock?
I constantly marvel at the sheer levels of exposure whenever Wrexham or Birmingham City are televised. They play each other tonight, and has ever an English League One fixture drawn so much attention across the globe?
Thereâ€™s plenty to unpick here. Both clubs have their celebrity faces, with Tom Brady in Birminghamâ€™s corner and Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney steering the good ship Wrexham. Both are up at the top end of League One, well in with a shout of promotion to the Championship. At this level, both have ridiculous financial might.
But the landscape would change in the Championship because, as Richard Sutcliffe explains, financial fair play rules differ when teams jump up from League One. Losses are restricted to Â£39m over three years. Hollywoodâ€™s finest canâ€™t just spend whatever it takes to reach the Premier League. Thatâ€™s not to say Wrexham and Birmingham wonâ€™t get there â€” but for Wrexham especially, next season is when we might discover if the sky is the limit.
- Wrexhamâ€™s James McClean appears to have escaped largely unscathed from a car crash yesterday. Whether he features this evening is another matter.
Around The Athletic FC
- Footballers, such as Lensâ€™ Florian Sotoca, who shoot a lot but donâ€™t score. What are they doing (apart from doing it wrong)?
- Retired basketball star Carmelo Anthony, who bought Puerto Rico FC in 2015, is embroiled in a $500m legal case involving Major League Soccer in the United States.
- Another great video from Tifo Football, outlining why fifth place in the Premier League is worth its weight in gold this season. Itâ€™s Champions League-related. Isnâ€™t everything?
- We followed up Mondayâ€™s musings about Andoni Iraola with a podcast about him (on Apple and Spotify). A fit-again Tyler Adams is making a huge difference to Bournemouthâ€™s system.
- Most clicked in yesterdayâ€™s TAFC: Unitedâ€™s broken television.

League One: Wrexham vs Birmingham City, 3pm/8pm â€” Paramount+/Sky Sports.
And finallyâ€¦
The oldest derby in world football first took place in 1860. It wasnâ€™t in Milan or Glasgow or Liverpool or Buenos Aires â€” but in the city of Sheffield, deep in mining country in the north of England.
Advertisement
Hallam versus Sheffield FC is that very rivalry, initiated on Boxing Day 165 years ago. Sheffield (an eighth-tier side) are also the oldest football club on the planet. Despite average crowds of 300, their fame has attracted 6,000 members from 54 countries, including Brazil and Kazakhstan.
Hostilities with Hallam were resumed this week after a 13-year hiatus. The Athletic went to watch â€” and found that the mantra of no pyro, no party applied, even this far off the beaten track.
(Top photo: David Ramos/UEFA via Getty Images)
